questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the WHO definition of health?
questions.solution:
According to the WHO, health is “a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity”.

In recent years, the definition has been modified to also include the ability to lead a “socially and economically productive life.”

questions.text: Which of the following is the biomedical concept of disease based upon?

choices.text: Combination of social, economic and political influences

questions.solution:
The biomedical concept of disease is based on the germ theory of disease, which was postulated by Louis Pasteur.

The germ theory of disease states that microorganisms known as pathogens or germs can lead to disease. It was criticized that it did not include environmental, social, psychological, and cultural determinants of health.  

The ecological concept of disease states that disease is the maladjustment of the human organism to the environment.

The psychosocial concept of disease hypothesised that health is also influenced by social, psychological, cultural and economic factors as well.

The holistic concept of disease includes all the above concepts to describe health.

questions.text: Which of the following is a mortality indicator?
questions.solution:
Life expectancy is a positive mortality indicator. 

A set of values that measure the rate of mortality or death is known as mortality indicators.

Disability-adjusted life years (DALY), health adjusted life expectancy (HALE), and Sullivan’s Index are disability rates.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is tasked with measuring the overall health status of a community using a morbidity indicator. Which of the following indicators will she not use?

choices.text: Number of days of restricted activity

questions.solution:
Number of days of restricted activity is a disability indicator. 

Morbidity is defined as public health outcomes focusing on diseases, traumas, or injury. Morbidity indicators can be used to measure the overall health and extent of healthcare utilisation in a given population.

Disability is defined as public health outcomes related to health conditions that include limitations in personal activities and societal participation. There are two types of disability indicators as follows:

  • Event type indicators-
    • Number of days of restricted activity
    • Bed disability days
    • Work loss days (or school loss days) within a specified period
  • Person type indicators-
    • Limitation of mobility: e.g confined to bed
    • Limitation of activity: e.g limitation to perform the basic activities of daily living such as eating and going to the toilet

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.

In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following indicators can be used to estimate the number of years a newborn would be expected to live in full health based on the current rates of ill health and mortality?
questions.solution:
HALE (Health Adjusted Life Expectancy) is an indicator that can be used to estimate the number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health based on the current rates of ill health and mortality.

HALE is calculated using the life expectancy at birth with an adjustment for time spent in poor health. It captures both fatal and non-fatal health outcomes of average levels of population health. It is also sensitive to changes over time or differences between countries in the distribution of health states.

Sullivan's index is also known as disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) or active life expectancy. It is the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability if the current patterns of mortality and disability continue to apply. It doesn’t take into account premature death. As HALE includes not just disability but the larger definition of poor health, it is a better option with respect to the question.

questions.text: While assessing the health needs of a community, an epidemiologist is tasked with estimating the burden of cholera in the area. Which of the following is the simplest measure he can use?
questions.solution:
The proportional mortality rate is the simplest measure of estimating the burden of disease in the community. It signifies the proportion of all deaths that can be attributed to the disease.

It is calculated as follows:

Proportional mortality rate of a disease = (No. of deaths due to that disease in the year/ Total no. of deaths in the year) *100.

Option A: Case fatality rate measures the risk of persons dying from a certain disease within a given time period. It measures the killing power of a disease. It is used to link mortality to morbidity.

Option B: Incidence measures the rate at which new cases are occurring in a population. It is not influenced by the duration of the disease. The use of incidence is generally restricted to acute diseases.

Option C: Crude death rate is considered a fair indicator of the comparative health of the people. It is the rate of total deaths in a year compared to the mid-year population.

questions.text: You are researching the overall burden of COVID on a given population. Which of the following disability indicators is the best measure of this?
questions.solution:
Disability adjusted life years (DALY) is the best measure of the overall burden of a disease in a defined population. It is also the best measure of the effectiveness of interventions. 

DALY is calculated as - Years of lost life prematurely (YLL) + Years lost to disability (YLD). It can measure both mortality and disability together. 

As DALY is affected by premature loss of life, conditions that affect younger individuals like road traffic accidents have a high DALY. In comparison to this, Alzheimer's disease has a lower DALY as it is a disease that mostly develops during old age and so has a lower YLL.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a health utilisation rate?

choices.text: Average length of stay in hospital

questions.solution:
Bed disability days is not a utilisation rate. It is an event-type disability indicator. It is defined as the number of days a person spent in a hospital bed due to illness or injury.

Health utilisation rate is defined as the number of people making use of the available health services to the total number of individuals in that population. 

Health utilisation rates include: 

  • Proportion of infants immunized against 9 diseases in the expanded program on immunization (EPI)
  • Proportion of women receiving antenatal care and supervised delivery 
  • Percentage of population using family planning methods
  • Bed occupancy rate
  • Average length of stay in the hospital
  • Bed turnover ratio

questions.text: As the medical superintendent of a hospital, you wish to optimise the utilization of health services. What bed turnover interval should you aim for?
questions.solution:
For optimum utilization of health services in a hospital, bed turnover interval must always be slightly positive.

Bed turnover interval is defined as the time interval where a hospital bed is left unoccupied following a patient’s discharge till the next patient occupies it after admission.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator of availability, utilization, and effectiveness of health services?
questions.solution:
Infant mortality rate (IMR) is the best indicator of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of health care. It is a very sensitive indicator.

Infant mortality rate (IMR)= Number of deaths in the first year of life/Number of live births x 1000

It is also one of the best indicators of state failure. It is the most universally accepted health status indicator of the whole population and of the socio-economic status in which they live.

Note: The best indicator of socio-economic development is the under-5 mortality rate.

questions.text: While reviewing a national health programme,  you are asked to assess the cost-effectiveness of the interventions provided under it. Which indicator will you use to measure this?
questions.solution:
QALY(Quality Adjusted Life Years) is used in assessing the cost-effectiveness (value of money) of a medical intervention. It is a measure of both the quality and quantity of life lived. It indicates the number of years of life that would be added by the intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a socio-economic determinant of health?
questions.solution:
Lifestyle is a behavioural and socio-cultural determinant of health. It is not a socio-economic determinant.

Socio-economic determinants of health are the following:

  • Economic status (per capita GNP)
  • Education
  • Occupation
  • Political system  

Lifestyle is simply the way people live. It reflects our social values, attitudes, and activities. It is composed of: 

  • Cultural patterns (daily nutrition, superstitions)
  • Behavioral patterns (personal hygiene, sedentary life)
  • Lifelong personal habits (e.g. smoking, alcoholism) 

Lifestyle is learned by social interaction with parents, siblings, friends, school, and mass media.  

Our political system determines our health. It can help shape community health services with regards to resource allocation, manpower policy, choice of technology, and the degree to which these services are made available & accessible to all segments of the society.

The percentage of GDP spent on health is an indicator of political commitment. WHO recommends at least 5% of GDP to be spent on health care. India spends about 2.1 % of its GDP on health(budget 2022-23).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a socio-economic indicator of health?
questions.solution:
Annual family income is not a socioeconomic indicator of health. 

Socio-economic indicators of health (mnemonic: H – FLAGGED):

  • Housing (number of persons per room)
  • Family size
  • Literacy rate (especially female literacy rate)
  • Availability of per capita calorie
  • GNP per capita
  • Growth rate of population
  • UnEmployment level
  • Dependency ratio

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding positive health in today’s world?

choices.text: It is dependent on social, economic, and cultural determinants
It is a mirage because of changing environment
It means that the body and mind are at peace
It includes provision of free health camps by the government

questions.solution:
The provision of free health camps by the government is a concept of state medicine.

Health does not merely mean the absence of disease or provision of diagnostic, curative, and preventive services. It is a state of physical, mental, and social well-being. 

The state of positive health is based on the idea of perfect functioning of the body and mind. According to this concept, health is:

  • Biologically a state in which every cell and organ in the body is functioning at optimum capacity
  • Psychologically a state in which the individual feels a sense of perfect well-being and mastery over his environment
  • Socially a state in which the individual's capacities for participation in the social system are optimal

This concept is too idealistic and can never become a reality. Humans can never be so perfectly adapted to the environment because everything in our life is subject to change.

As the goal of positive health is unattainable, a broader concept of improving the quality of life has emerged. This highlights that positive health depends on medical action and also on economic, cultural, and social factors in the community.

questions.text: As per the WHO, which of the following is not included in the standard of living?
questions.solution:
Social security is a component of the level of living as per the United Nations and not standard of living.

According to the WHO, the standard of living includes:

  • Income and occupation
  • Standards of housing, sanitation, and nutrition
  • Level of provision of health, educational, and recreational services

It depends on per capita GNP.

questions.text:
Which of the following are components of the physical quality of life index (PQLI)?
  1. Infant mortality rate
  2. Life expectancy at birth

Infant mortality rate, literacy rate, and life expectancy at 1 year of age are the components of the physical quality of life index (PQLI).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the human development index (HDI)?
questions.solution:
Infant mortality rate (IMR) is not a component of HDI. It is a component of the physical quality of life index (PQLI). 

The human development index (HDI) is used to compare living standards in different countries. It includes the following dimensions or components:

Component  Indicator  Index
Longevity Life expectancy at birth Life expectancy index
Knowledge Literacy and enrolment Education index
Income GNI per capita US$ (purchasing power parity-PPP) GNI index (income index)

Each dimension index is calculated using the formula: Dimension Index = (Actual Value - Minimum Value)/(Maximum Value - Minimum Value)

HDI is the geometric mean of the three indices: ILife1/3 x    IEducation1/3    x    IIncome1/3.  

As per the Human Development Report 2023-2024, India's Human Development Index (HDI) value is 0.644. This places India at 134th out of 193 countries.

questions.text: What are the minimum and maximum values established for the calculation of the life expectancy index in HDI?
questions.solution:
The minimum value established for the calculation of the life expectancy index in HDI is 20 years and the maximum is 85 years.

These minimum and maximum values are used to calculate the dimension indices in HDI and are called goalposts.

Each dimension index is calculated using the formula:

Dimension Index = (Actual Value - Minimum Value)/(Maximum Value - Minimum Value).

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the education index used for calculating the HDI?

choices.text: It includes expected years of schooling
Adult literacy rate is not considered
Minimum and maximum values are based on global data

questions.solution:
The gross enrollment ratio is no longer used in obtaining the education index in HDI. It was used as an indicator earlier.

The education index is calculated by taking into account the mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling. Maximum and minimum values are based on global data.

Adult literacy rate and gross enrollment ratio were used as indicators before 2009.

questions.text: Which of the following indices measures the deprivation in basic dimensions of the country in human development?
questions.solution:
Human poverty index (HPI) measures deprivation in basic dimensions of human development.

HPI-1 is used for developing countries and HPI-2 is used for developed countries. It is based upon the following indicators:

 

Human Poverty Index (HPI-1) for developing countries 

 Human Poverty Index (HPI-2) for selected OECD countries 
A long and healthy life 

Probability at birth of not surviving to age 40

 Probability at birth of not surviving to age 60
Knowledge Adult illiteracy rate Percentage of adults lacking functional literacy skills
A decent standard of living

Percentage of the population not using an improved water source 

Percentage of children underweight for age

Deprivation of a decent standard of living

 Percentage of people living below the poverty line 
Social exclusion Not included as a dimension Long term unemployment rate

The range of HPI is from 0 to 100. The term HPI has now been replaced with multidimensional poverty index (MPI).

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Ottawa charter for health promotion?
questions.solution:
Building social security is not included in the Ottawa charter for health promotion. 

The first international conference for health promotion was held in Ottawa on 21st Nov 1986. It produced a charter known as the Ottawa charter.

The charter identified five key action areas as given below:

  • Build healthy public policy
  • Create supportive environment for health
  • Strengthen community action for health
  • Develop personal skills
  • Reorient health services
